title: Histograms
text:
A histogram is a graph that compares the frequency (y-axis) of any categorical or numeric variable (x-axis). In other words, it measures how often a value from the x-axis appears in a data set.
Here is the framework of a histogram:









In the penguin dataset, we can use a histogram to determine how often each bill depth (variable: bill_depth_mm) value appears in the dataset.
Here, there is a deviation from the ggplot framework in the home page. “bins” is used to tell R how many bars to create in your histogram. You can change this number as needed.

ggplot(data=penguins, mapping=aes(x=bill_depth_mm, na.rm=TRUE))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20)+
  labs(title="Distribution of Antarctic Penguin Bill Depth", x="Bill depth (mm)", y="Frequency")

Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_bin()`).









Now, create a histogram to see the distribution of chick weights (variable “weight”) using the chickWeight dataset.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Histograms
text:
A histogram is a graph that compares the frequency (y-axis) of any categorical or numeric variable (x-axis). In other words, it measures how often a value from the x-axis appears in a data set.
Here is the framework of a histogram:









In the penguin dataset, we can use a histogram to determine how often each bill depth (variable: bill_depth_mm) value appears in the dataset.
Here, there is a deviation from the ggplot framework in the home page. “bins” is used to tell R how many bars to create in your histogram. You can change this number as needed.

ggplot(data=penguins, mapping=aes(x=bill_depth_mm, na.rm=TRUE))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20)+
  labs(title="Distribution of Antarctic Penguin Bill Depth", x="Bill depth (mm)", y="Frequency")

(`stat_bin()`).









Now, create a histogram to see the distribution of chick weights (variable “weight”) using the chickWeight dataset.

title: Box Plots
text:
A box plot is a graph that shows a numeric summary (y-axis) of either a categorical or numerical variable (x-axis). It gives information on the range of the data with either end of the plot.
The “box,” as shown below, represents three values: the 25th percentile, median (50th percentile), and the 75th percentile. Each horizontal bar corresponds to a number where that percentage of the data falls below. In other words, the horizontal bar closest to the x-axis represents where 25% of the data falls below, the bar in between the box is the median, or where 50% of the data fall below, and the furthest horizontal bar represents where 75% of the data falls below.
The vertical lines that emerge from the box are called whiskers. The whisker closest to the x-axis represents the minimum calculated by subtracting three times the interquartile range (75th percentile-25th percentile) from the value for the 25th percentile. The furthest whisker from the x-axis represents the maximum calculated by subtracting three times the interquartile range from the 75th percentile.
Here is the framework of a box plot.









Using the penguin dataset, we can compare the flipper lengths (variable: flipper_length_mm) of the different species (variable: species) of penguins.

ggplot(data=penguins, mapping = aes(x=species, y=flipper_length_mm))+
  geom_boxplot()+
  labs(x="Species of Antarctic penguin", y="Flipper length (mm)", title = "Species of Antarctic penguins have different flipper lengths")

Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_boxplot()`).









For the Adelie penguins, there are outliers on either side of the whiskers. These are values fall short/exceed the whisker value calculation.
Now, compare the flipper lengths (variable: flipper_length_mm) of the different sexes (variable: sex) of penguins

title: Home
text:
1 What is ggplot2?
The grammar of graphics package in R called ggplot2 is used to generate data visualizations. It breaks down the components of a plot, so you can adjust its aesthetics (size or intensity of plot points, colors, spatial arrangement of the elements) for a variety of graph types. Here, we will use ggplot2 to code:

Histograms
Box plots
Bar charts
Scatterplots

title: Home
text:
2 Installing ggplot2
To install ggplot into your environment, run the code
install.packages("ggplot2")
To load ggplot into your environment, run
library(ggplot2)
In this tutorial, don’t worry about installing tidyverse. However, you must install it on any of your personal projects.

title: Home
text:
3 Elements of a graph
There are key features in all graphs, including:
A title: A good title should be the conclusion of your data analysis, or the relationship of your X and Y axes.
Axes: The X and Y axis should have their respective types of data. Each graph tutorial will guide you on what type of data goes on which axis.
Colors: Using colors can help guide your audience on what trend, if any, you want to emphasize. It is important to note that they should be used sparingly. While they may look pretty, having too many colors can be distracting of your data’s big picture.
Legends: To prevent the graph from being too busy, consider using a legend to explain your graph’s features.

title: Home
text:
4 What makes a graph good?
Anyone should be able to look at a graph and understand your data without the context of your research. Take a step back from your code and ask yourself:
What is this graph telling me? What is the relationship between the X and Y variables?
The key to making a graph comprehensible is to make its story as clear as possible. Use the elements of your graph as tools to convey this story.

title: Home
text:
5 Types of data
Identifying the types of data you have will help you identify the type of graph you’ll need. There are two types of data with two subcategories for each: 
Categorical: data that are arranged in groups
              Nominal: there is no priority or ranking in groups 
              Eg. yes or no, favorite colors
              Ordinal: There is structure within the groups
              Eg small, medium, and large or cold, warm, and hot
Numerical: all things numbers
Continuous: Decimal/fractional integers
Discrete: Whole integers

title: Home
text:
6 Data in this tutorial
We will be using three different data sets to hone in on our data science skills.

Palmer penguins: This data set gives insight on the bill length, bill depth, flipper length, body mass, sex, and year of data collection of various Antarctic penguins. 


#penguin data


#selecting all columns


#using gt


Chick weight: This data set tracks the weight of chicks in grams on different diets over 21 days. The diet types are as follows:
Diet 1: Normal feed with a 10% protein replacement
Diet 2: Normal feed with a 20% protein replacement
Diet 3: Normal feed with a 40% protein replacement
Diet 4: Normal feed, controlled group



#selecting chick weight columns


#gt chick weights


Presidents: This data set tracks the quarterly approval ratings of US presidents from 1945-1975.


#select president columns


#gt presidents

Take a look at each data set by running their respective code chunks. Do you notice any trends? What variables interest you?

title: Home
text:
7 ggplot Code Framework
In order to use ggplot, there here is a skeletal framework:
#| echo: fenced #| results: hide ggplot(data=dataset, mapping=aes(x=xVariable, y=yVariable))+ geom_typeOfPlot()+ labs(title=“Your title”, x=“Name of X variable”, y=“Your Y variable”)
Let’s break down each part of this graph:

First, are calling on the ggplot function.
Then, we are asking R to look through our dataset.
The mapping=aes is used to change elements in your graph that are in the “Tips and Tricks” section of this site.
After that, we are explicitly telling R what variables we want on each axis.
Next, we are specifying which type of graph we want R to make.
Finally, we call on the labs function to rename our axes with our variable names, making sure to include units when necessary.

Now, we are ready to start coding! Let’s learn about some data visualizations we can make with R.
